## In `R`...

categorical variables can have either `character` *or* `factor` data types

</br>

. . .

`factor` -- structured & fixed number of levels / options

-   can be ordered or unordered

</br>

. . .

`character` -- unstructured & variable number of levels

-   is inherently unordered

## 

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em;"}
If you wanted means for each level of a categorical variable, what would you do?
:::

## Trout Size

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
The HJ Andrews Experimental Forest houses one of the larges long-term ecological research stations, specifically researching cutthroat trout and salamanders in clear cut or old growth sections of Mack Creek.
:::

</br>


::: {.cell output-location='fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
trout %>% 
  group_by(section) %>% 
  summarize(mean_length = mean(length_1_mm, na.rm = TRUE)
            )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  section                               mean_length
  <chr>                                       <dbl>
1 clear cut forest                             85.3
2 upstream old growth coniferous forest        81.4
```
:::
:::


. . .

</br>

<center>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
**Why `na.rm = TRUE`?**
:::

</center>

## Classifying Channel Types

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
The channels of the Mack Creek which were sampled were classified into the following groups:
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="15%"}
`"C"`

`"I"`

`"IP"`

`"P"`

`"R"`

`"S"`

`"SC"`

`NA`
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="80%"}
cascade

riffle

isolated pool

pool

rapid

step (small falls)

side channel

not sampled by unit
:::
:::

## `filter()`-ing Specific Channel Types

::: {style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
The majority of the Cutthroat trout were captured in cascades (C), pools (P), and side channels (SC). Suppose we want to only retain these levels of the `unittype` variable.
:::

. . .

</br>

<center>**What would you do?**</center>

. . .

</br>


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
trout %>% 
  filter(unittype %in% c("C", "P", "SC"))
```
:::


. . .

</br>

<center>**Why use `%in%` instead of `==`?**</center>

## Incorporating Categorical Variables into Data Visualizations

::: incremental
-   As a variable on the `x`- or `y`-axis

-   As a `color` / `fill`

-   As a facet
:::

## Salamander Size

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_2_mm)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 14) + 
  labs(x = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=384}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
</br>

How would this histogram look if there was no variation in salamander length?

</br>

What are possible causes for the variation in salamander length?
:::
:::
:::

## Faceted Histograms


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_1_mm)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 14) + 
  facet_wrap(~ section, scales = "free") +
  labs(x = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/facet-hist-1.png){width=95%}
:::
:::


## Side-by-Side Boxplots

::: columns
::: {.column width="50"}

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_1_mm, 
                     y = species)
         ) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(x = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)", 
       y = "Salamander Species") 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/horizontal-boxplot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50"}

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(y = length_1_mm, 
                     x = species)
         ) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(y = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)", 
       x = "Salamander Species")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/vertical-boxplot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::

:::
:::

## Colors in Boxplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_1_mm, 
                       y = species, 
                       color = unittype)
         ) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(x = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)", 
       y = "Salamander Species", 
       color = "Channel Type")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-color-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768}
:::
:::


## Facets & Colors in Boxplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_1_mm, 
                       y = species, 
                       color = section)
         ) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  facet_wrap(~ unittype) + 
  labs(x = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)", 
       y = "Salamander Species", 
       color = "Section in Mack Creek")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-facets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Facets & Color in Scatterplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="false"}
ggplot(data = salamander, 
       mapping = aes(x = length_1_mm, 
                       y = weight_g, 
                       color = section)
         ) + 
  geom_point() + 
  facet_wrap(~species) +
  labs(y = "Snout to Tail Length (mm)", 
       x = "Year", 
       color = "Salamander Species")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week3-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-facets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
